content: Good picks GWG. Ballad of The Green Berets. The Marine Hymn. Men of Harlech ( as sung by the Welchmen at the Battle of Rorke's Drift ! ) Onward Christian Soldiers! { "Abide With Me", a hymn which is not really a Military Song, but was sung by the wounded and captured British troops in Holland during Operation Market Garden. You can see/hear it in "A Bridge Too Far". }

content: One of my favorites; Artist: Big & Rich Song: 8th of November Album: Comin' To Your City Big & Rich Sheet An appearance on "Imus in the Morning" youtube.com/watch?v=liG9UT4HiCg Said goodbye to his mamma As he left South Dakota To fight for the Red, White, and Blue. He was nineteen and green with a new M-16 Just doing what he had to do. He was dropped in the jungle Where the choppers would rumble With the smell of napalm in the air. And the sergeant said, "Look up ahead" Like a dark, evil cloud 1,200 came down on him and 29 more. They fought for their lives But most of them died In the 173rd Airborne. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around There were few men left standing that day. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965, the 8th of November. Now he's fifty-eight And his ponytail's grey But the battle still plays in his head. He limps when he walks, But he's strong when he talks About the shrapnel they left in his leg. He puts on a grey suit Over his Airborne tattoo And He ties it on one time a year And remembers the fallen, As he orders a tall one And swallows it down with his tears. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around There were few men left standing that day. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965, the 8th of November. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around There were few men left standing that day. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around, There were few men left standing that day. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965, the 8th of November. The 8th of November The 8th of November He said goodbye to his mamma As he left South Dakota To fight for the Red, White, and Blue. He was nineteen and green with a new M-16 Just doing what he had to do.

content: Rush Limbaugh's, Michael "Michael Savage" Weiner's and former Vice President Cheney's favorite song - which they all probably sang during the Viet-Nam War: I'm just a typical American boy from a typical American town I believe in God and Senator Todd and keeping old Castro down And when it came my time to serve I knew better dead than red But when I got to my old draft board, buddy, this is what I said: Sarge, I'm only eighteen, I got a ruptured spleen And I always carry a purse I got eyes like a bat, my feet are flat, and my asthma's getting worse Oh, think of my career, my sweetheart dear, and my poor old invalid aunt Besides, I ain't no fool, I'm a goin' to school, and I'm working in a defense plant I've got a dislocated disc and a racked up back I'm allergic to flowers and bugs And when bombshells hit, I get epileptic fits And I'm addicted to a thousand drugs I got the weakness woes, I can't touch my toes, I can hardly touch my knees And if the enemy came close to me I'd probably start to sneeze I hate Chou En Lai, and I hope he dies, but one thing you gotta see That someone's gotta go over there but that someone isn't me So I wish you well, Sarge, give 'em Hell Yeah, kill me a thousand or more And if you ever get a war without blood and gore Well I'll be the first to go Draft Dodger Rag by Phil Ochs

content: Army Blue (West Point chorus) The Corps (West Point - not Marines) Benny Havens, Oh! (West Point chorus) Faith of Our Fathers (US Hymn) Navy Hymn Theme from "We Were Soldiers ..." (sung by West Point chorus) Theme from M*A*S*H, aka "Suicide is Painless" (hey, a little love for the medics, please!) "Washington Post March" hell - most ANY march "Taps" "Amazing Grace" played by the Scots Regimental Bagpipes - guaranteed to raise the hairs all over your body "Soldier Boy" (the Shirelles) "Blue, Navy Blue" (Shelly Fabres??? not sure) Anti-war/military? The ones I like: "Fortunate Son" (CCR) "War" (What Is It Good For) "Fixin' to Die Rag" (Country Joe & the Fish) "I'm Proud to be an Okie from Muskcogee" On a related topic, what about songs that have "new" words made for the tunes? Like this one I remember from VN, to the tune of an old Edith Piaf song from around WWII: Dear Ma'am your son is dead, He bought the farm today, He put his O-2 down on ninety-six highway. He made a ROCK-et pass And then he BUST-ed his @ss Hmmm, Hmmm, Hmmmmmmm I always thought that was very touching.

content: Good picks GWG. Ballad of The Green Berets. The Marine Hymn. Men of Harlech ( as sung by the Welchmen at the Battle of Rorke's Drift ! ) Onward Christian Soldiers! { "Abide With Me", a hymn which is not really a Military Song, but was sung by the wounded and captured British troops in Holland during Operation Market Garden. You can see/hear it in "A Bridge Too Far". }

content: One of my favorites; Artist: Big & Rich Song: 8th of November Album: Comin' To Your City Big & Rich Sheet An appearance on "Imus in the Morning" youtube.com/watch?v=liG9UT4HiCg Said goodbye to his mamma As he left South Dakota To fight for the Red, White, and Blue. He was nineteen and green with a new M-16 Just doing what he had to do. He was dropped in the jungle Where the choppers would rumble With the smell of napalm in the air. And the sergeant said, "Look up ahead" Like a dark, evil cloud 1,200 came down on him and 29 more. They fought for their lives But most of them died In the 173rd Airborne. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around There were few men left standing that day. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965, the 8th of November. Now he's fifty-eight And his ponytail's grey But the battle still plays in his head. He limps when he walks, But he's strong when he talks About the shrapnel they left in his leg. He puts on a grey suit Over his Airborne tattoo And He ties it on one time a year And remembers the fallen, As he orders a tall one And swallows it down with his tears. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around There were few men left standing that day. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965, the 8th of November. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around There were few men left standing that day. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around, There were few men left standing that day. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965, the 8th of November. The 8th of November The 8th of November He said goodbye to his mamma As he left South Dakota To fight for the Red, White, and Blue. He was nineteen and green with a new M-16 Just doing what he had to do.

content: Rush Limbaugh's, Michael "Michael Savage" Weiner's and former Vice President Cheney's favorite song - which they all probably sang during the Viet-Nam War: I'm just a typical American boy from a typical American town I believe in God and Senator Todd and keeping old Castro down And when it came my time to serve I knew better dead than red But when I got to my old draft board, buddy, this is what I said: Sarge, I'm only eighteen, I got a ruptured spleen And I always carry a purse I got eyes like a bat, my feet are flat, and my asthma's getting worse Oh, think of my career, my sweetheart dear, and my poor old invalid aunt Besides, I ain't no fool, I'm a goin' to school, and I'm working in a defense plant I've got a dislocated disc and a racked up back I'm allergic to flowers and bugs And when bombshells hit, I get epileptic fits And I'm addicted to a thousand drugs I got the weakness woes, I can't touch my toes, I can hardly touch my knees And if the enemy came close to me I'd probably start to sneeze I hate Chou En Lai, and I hope he dies, but one thing you gotta see That someone's gotta go over there but that someone isn't me So I wish you well, Sarge, give 'em Hell Yeah, kill me a thousand or more And if you ever get a war without blood and gore Well I'll be the first to go Draft Dodger Rag by Phil Ochs

content: Army Blue (West Point chorus) The Corps (West Point - not Marines) Benny Havens, Oh! (West Point chorus) Faith of Our Fathers (US Hymn) Navy Hymn Theme from "We Were Soldiers ..." (sung by West Point chorus) Theme from M*A*S*H, aka "Suicide is Painless" (hey, a little love for the medics, please!) "Washington Post March" hell - most ANY march "Taps" "Amazing Grace" played by the Scots Regimental Bagpipes - guaranteed to raise the hairs all over your body "Soldier Boy" (the Shirelles) "Blue, Navy Blue" (Shelly Fabres??? not sure) Anti-war/military? The ones I like: "Fortunate Son" (CCR) "War" (What Is It Good For) "Fixin' to Die Rag" (Country Joe & the Fish) "I'm Proud to be an Okie from Muskcogee" On a related topic, what about songs that have "new" words made for the tunes? Like this one I remember from VN, to the tune of an old Edith Piaf song from around WWII: Dear Ma'am your son is dead, He bought the farm today, He put his O-2 down on ninety-six highway. He made a ROCK-et pass And then he BUST-ed his @ss Hmmm, Hmmm, Hmmmmmmm I always thought that was very touching.

content: Good picks GWG. Ballad of The Green Berets. The Marine Hymn. Men of Harlech ( as sung by the Welchmen at the Battle of Rorke's Drift ! ) Onward Christian Soldiers! { "Abide With Me", a hymn which is not really a Military Song, but was sung by the wounded and captured British troops in Holland during Operation Market Garden. You can see/hear it in "A Bridge Too Far". }

content: One of my favorites; Artist: Big & Rich Song: 8th of November Album: Comin' To Your City Big & Rich Sheet An appearance on "Imus in the Morning" youtube.com/watch?v=liG9UT4HiCg Said goodbye to his mamma As he left South Dakota To fight for the Red, White, and Blue. He was nineteen and green with a new M-16 Just doing what he had to do. He was dropped in the jungle Where the choppers would rumble With the smell of napalm in the air. And the sergeant said, "Look up ahead" Like a dark, evil cloud 1,200 came down on him and 29 more. They fought for their lives But most of them died In the 173rd Airborne. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around There were few men left standing that day. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965, the 8th of November. Now he's fifty-eight And his ponytail's grey But the battle still plays in his head. He limps when he walks, But he's strong when he talks About the shrapnel they left in his leg. He puts on a grey suit Over his Airborne tattoo And He ties it on one time a year And remembers the fallen, As he orders a tall one And swallows it down with his tears. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around There were few men left standing that day. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965, the 8th of November. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around There were few men left standing that day. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around, There were few men left standing that day. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965, the 8th of November. The 8th of November The 8th of November He said goodbye to his mamma As he left South Dakota To fight for the Red, White, and Blue. He was nineteen and green with a new M-16 Just doing what he had to do.

content: Rush Limbaugh's, Michael "Michael Savage" Weiner's and former Vice President Cheney's favorite song - which they all probably sang during the Viet-Nam War: I'm just a typical American boy from a typical American town I believe in God and Senator Todd and keeping old Castro down And when it came my time to serve I knew better dead than red But when I got to my old draft board, buddy, this is what I said: Sarge, I'm only eighteen, I got a ruptured spleen And I always carry a purse I got eyes like a bat, my feet are flat, and my asthma's getting worse Oh, think of my career, my sweetheart dear, and my poor old invalid aunt Besides, I ain't no fool, I'm a goin' to school, and I'm working in a defense plant I've got a dislocated disc and a racked up back I'm allergic to flowers and bugs And when bombshells hit, I get epileptic fits And I'm addicted to a thousand drugs I got the weakness woes, I can't touch my toes, I can hardly touch my knees And if the enemy came close to me I'd probably start to sneeze I hate Chou En Lai, and I hope he dies, but one thing you gotta see That someone's gotta go over there but that someone isn't me So I wish you well, Sarge, give 'em Hell Yeah, kill me a thousand or more And if you ever get a war without blood and gore Well I'll be the first to go Draft Dodger Rag by Phil Ochs

And the sergeant said, "Look up ahead" Like a dark, evil cloud 1,200 came down on him and 29 more. They fought for their lives But most of them died In the 173rd Airborne. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around There were few men left standing that day. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965, the 8th of November. Now he's fifty-eight And his ponytail's grey But the battle still plays in his head. He limps when he walks, But he's strong when he talks About the shrapnel they left in his leg. He puts on a grey suit Over his Airborne tattoo And He ties it on one time a year And remembers the fallen, As he orders a tall one And swallows it down with his tears. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around There were few men left standing that day. content: Army Blue (West Point chorus) The Corps (West Point - not Marines) Benny Havens, Oh! (West Point chorus) Faith of Our Fathers (US Hymn) Navy Hymn Theme from "We Were Soldiers ..." (sung by West Point chorus) Theme from M*A*S*H, aka "Suicide is Painless" (hey, a little love for the medics, please!) "Washington Post March" hell - most ANY march "Taps" "Amazing Grace" played by the Scots Regimental Bagpipes - guaranteed to raise the hairs all over your body "Soldier Boy" (the Shirelles) "Blue, Navy Blue" (Shelly Fabres??? not sure) Anti-war/military? The ones I like: "Fortunate Son" (CCR) "War" (What Is It Good For) "Fixin' to Die Rag" (Country Joe & the Fish) "I'm Proud to be an Okie from Muskcogee" On a related topic, what about songs that have "new" words made for the tunes? Like this one I remember from VN, to the tune of an old Edith Piaf song from around WWII: Dear Ma'am your son is dead, He bought the farm today, He put his O-2 down on ninety-six highway. He made a ROCK-et pass And then he BUST-ed his @ss Hmmm, Hmmm, Hmmmmmmm I always thought that was very touching.

content: Good picks GWG. Ballad of The Green Berets. The Marine Hymn. Men of Harlech ( as sung by the Welchmen at the Battle of Rorke's Drift ! ) Onward Christian Soldiers! { "Abide With Me", a hymn which is not really a Military Song, but was sung by the wounded and captured British troops in Holland during Operation Market Garden. You can see/hear it in "A Bridge Too Far". }

content: Rush Limbaugh's, Michael "Michael Savage" Weiner's and former Vice President Cheney's favorite song - which they all probably sang during the Viet-Nam War: I'm just a typical American boy from a typical American town I believe in God and Senator Todd and keeping old Castro down And when it came my time to serve I knew better dead than red But when I got to my old draft board, buddy, this is what I said: Sarge, I'm only eighteen, I got a ruptured spleen And I always carry a purse I got eyes like a bat, my feet are flat, and my asthma's getting worse Oh, think of my career, my sweetheart dear, and my poor old invalid aunt Besides, I ain't no fool, I'm a goin' to school, and I'm working in a defense plant I've got a dislocated disc and a racked up back I'm allergic to flowers and bugs And when bombshells hit, I get epileptic fits And I'm addicted to a thousand drugs I got the weakness woes, I can't touch my toes, I can hardly touch my knees And if the enemy came close to me I'd probably start to sneeze I hate Chou En Lai, and I hope he dies, but one thing you gotta see That someone's gotta go over there but that someone isn't me So I wish you well, Sarge, give 'em Hell Yeah, kill me a thousand or more And if you ever get a war without blood and gore Well I'll be the first to go Draft Dodger Rag by Phil Ochs

content: quote: Originally posted by 21yrsUSCGUSCS: One of my favorites; Artist: Big & Rich Song: 8th of November Album: Comin' To Your City Big & Rich Sheet An appearance on "Imus in the Morning" youtube.com/watch?v=liG9UT4HiCg Said goodbye to his mamma As he left South Dakota To fight for the Red, White, and Blue. He was nineteen and green with a new M-16 Just doing what he had to do. He was dropped in the jungle Where the choppers would rumble With the smell of napalm in the air. And the sergeant said, "Look up ahead" Like a dark, evil cloud 1,200 came down on him and 29 more. They fought for their lives But most of them died In the 173rd Airborne. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around There were few men left standing that day. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965, the 8th of November. Now he's fifty-eight And his ponytail's grey But the battle still plays in his head. He limps when he walks, But he's strong when he talks About the shrapnel they left in his leg. He puts on a grey suit Over his Airborne tattoo And He ties it on one time a year And remembers the fallen, As he orders a tall one And swallows it down with his tears. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around There were few men left standing that day. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965, the 8th of November. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around There were few men left standing that day. (Chorus) On the 8th of November, The angels were crying As they carried his brothers away. With the fire raining down And the Hell all around, There were few men left standing that day. Saw the eagle fly, Through a clear, blue sky 1965, the 8th of November. The 8th of November The 8th of November He said goodbye to his mamma As he left South Dakota To fight for the Red, White, and Blue. He was nineteen and green with a new M-16 Just doing what he had to do. I hadn't heard this one till recently but it's a good new song. (Niles Harris, the inspriration for the song, was my 1SGT just before he retired)(Quite a character) I like many of the old standby's listed here though.

content: "..... give me an F, give me a U, give me a C, give me a K, whats that spell?, Whats that spell?.... what are we fighting for, dont ask me I don't give a damn, my next stop is Viet nam...." "....whoopie, we're all gonna die....." we got a big kick out of this song while in VN. One Flag......One Heart......One Nation............EVERMORE

content: Army Blue (West Point chorus) The Corps (West Point - not Marines) Benny Havens, Oh! (West Point chorus) Faith of Our Fathers (US Hymn) Navy Hymn Theme from "We Were Soldiers ..." (sung by West Point chorus) Theme from M*A*S*H, aka "Suicide is Painless" (hey, a little love for the medics, please!) "Washington Post March" hell - most ANY march "Taps" "Amazing Grace" played by the Scots Regimental Bagpipes - guaranteed to raise the hairs all over your body "Soldier Boy" (the Shirelles) "Blue, Navy Blue" (Shelly Fabres??? not sure) Anti-war/military? The ones I like: "Fortunate Son" (CCR) "War" (What Is It Good For) "Fixin' to Die Rag" (Country Joe & the Fish) "I'm Proud to be an Okie from Muskcogee" On a related topic, what about songs that have "new" words made for the tunes? Like this one I remember from VN, to the tune of an old Edith Piaf song from around WWII: Dear Ma'am your son is dead, He bought the farm today, He put his O-2 down on ninety-six highway. He made a ROCK-et pass And then he BUST-ed his @ss Hmmm, Hmmm, Hmmmmmmm I always thought that was very touching.
